column3: Does the state have a plan that details steps it will take to address climate change?  (0 = no; 1 = yes)
column4: Center for Climate and Energy Solutions; Morey and Kirsch (2016): Retail Choice in Electricity: What have we Learned in 20 Years?. EMRF.

column3: Does a state have a community solar program? (0=no; 1=yes)
column4: National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL)

column3: Does the state adopt California's Car emissions standards (which are more stringent than the federal level)? (0 = no; 1 = yes)
column4: Maryland Department of the Environment. States adopting California's clean car standards; Wikipedia ``United States vehicle emission standards''

column3: Does the state have a binding cap on greenhouse gas emissions in the utility sector (eg; RGGI; WCI)?  (0 = no; 1 = yes)
column4: C2ES; Jonathan L. Ramseur: The regional greenhouse gas initiative: Lessons learned and issues for policy makers; California Environmental Protection Agency: Assembly Bill 32 overview.

column1: State preemption of local gas bans
column3: Does the state prohibit local bans on gas hookups in buildings? 0=No; 1=Yes
column4: NPR All Things Considered: ``As Cities Grapple With Climate Change; Gas Utilities Fight To Stay In Business''

column3: Does the state have a public benefit fund for renewable energy and energy efficiency?  (0 = no; 1 = yes)
column4: C2ES; American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy (ACEEE); Database of State Incentives for Renewables and Efficiency (DSIRE); National Governors Association: Clean electricity: Public benefits funds.

column3: Does the state require electricity providers to disclose their fuel sources? (0 = no; 1 = yes)
column4: DSIRE; Prasad; M. and Munch: S. State-level renewable electricity policies and reductions in carbon emissions. (Energy Policy; 2012)

column3: Does the state have performance standards designed to reduce CO2 emissions?  (0 = no; 1 = yes)
column4: C2ES; Morey and Kirsch: Retail Choice in Electricity: What have we Learned in 20 Years?. (EMRF; 2016)

column3: 0 = net metering not adopted; 1 = net metering or comparable policy (feed-in tariff) adopted
column4: Correlates of State Policy Project (CSPP)

column3: Has the state authorized Property Assessed Clean Energy programs? (0=no; 1=yes)
column4: PACENation; DSIRE

column3: Does the state have energy efficiency and other green building requirements for public buildings? (0=no; 1=yes)
column4: CSPP

column3: Does the state have complete streets policies? (0 = none; 1 = plan/design guide; 2 = laws/ordinances/resolutions/directives)
column4: SmartGrowth America

column3: Does the state have energy efficiency targets? (0 = none; 1 = voluntary/unenforceable; 2 = mandatory)
column4: C2ES; Morey and Kirsch: Retail Choice in Electricity: What have we Learned in 20 Years?. (EMRF; 2016)

column3: Does the state have a tax credit for residential solar installations? (0 = No legislation; 1 = State approved local option; 2 = State mandated credit or exemption system)
column4: sunrun.com; energysage.com; Wholesale Solar; Lexis Nexis/State Governments: State statutes

column3: Does the state have its own version of the federal National Environmental Policy Act? (0 = none; 1 = applies to state governments only; 2 =also applies to  local governments and/or private entities)
column4: ballotpedia.org;  Marchman: ``Little NEPAs:'' State equivalents to the National Environmental Policy act in Indiana; Minnesota; and Wisconsin (2012).Lexis Nexis/State Governments: State statutes Yost: NEPA's progeny: State environmental policy acts. (News and Analysis; 3(1) 1973)

column3: Does the state require all power plants to register and record their emissions? (0 = none; 1 = voluntary; 2 = mandatory)
column4: C2ES; Morey and Kirsch: Retail Choice in Electricity: What have we Learned in 20 Years?. (EMRF; 2016)

column3: Does the state have a goal for emission reduction levels by a certain time period? (0 = none; 1 = executive order; 2 = statutory/public utilty commission order)
column4: C2ES; Morey and Kirsch: Retail Choice in Electricity: What have we Learned in 20 Years?. (EMRF; 2016)

column3: Does the state have energy efficiency programs for low-income individuals? (0 = none; 1 = legislative/regulatory requirements; utility cost-effectivenesss rules established; OR levels of spending on low-income EE less than 6.50 USD per low-income resident; 2 = legislative/regulatory requirements and utility cost-effectivenesss rules established; or levels of spending on low-income EE less than 13 USD per low-income resident)
column4: ACEEE

column3: Does the state require utilities to offer customers electricity generated from renewable sources? (0 = none; 1 = voluntary; 2 = mandatory)
column4: C2ES; Morey and Kirsch: Retail Choice in Electricity: What have we Learned in 20 Years?. (EMRF; 2016)

column3: Does the state compensate utilities for selling less electricity? (0 = none; 1 = performance based incentives; 2 = non-decoupling energy efficiency adjustment; 3 = decoupled)
column4: C2ES; Morey and Kirsch: Retail Choice in Electricity: What have we Learned in 20 Years?. (EMRF; 2016)

column3: Does a state have an RPS? (0 = no target; 1 = voluntary or less than 1percent; 2 = mandatory less than 100percent; 3 = mandatory 100percent)
column4: National Council of State Legislatures (NCSL)

column3: Does the state compensate utilities for selling less gas?  (0 = none; 1 = performance based incentives; 2 = non-decoupling energy efficiency adjustment; 3 = decoupled)
column4: C2ES; ACEEE; NCSL

column3: What is the state's energy efficiency resource standard (EERS)? An EERS is a quantitative; long-term energy savings target for utilities that requires them to procure a percentage of their future electricity and natural gas needs using energy efficiency measures. (continuous percent)
column4: ACEEE

column3: What is the state's RPS target (enforceable standards only)? (continuous percent)
column4: DSIRE; Solomon and Zhou (2021): Renewable Portfolio Standards: Do Voluntary Goals vs. Mandatory Standards Make a Difference? (Review of Policy Research)

column3: What is the state's gas tax level?
